title: Does every mathematical truth necessarily have more than one proof? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since there are true yet unprovable in a given incomplete theory (such theories make up the bulk of math) statements, the answer is no. In complete systems, this (as far as I know) mostly remains an open question sith some exceptions like analytical tableaux wherein, for example, there is exactly one proof (via  rule) that  is a contradictory formula. Hope, that helps.
